Common disadvantages of longitudinal research include: 1. Time-consuming and expensive, 2. Participant attrition (people drop out over time), 3. Possible changes in the environment or society that can affect the results (historical events, cultural shifts), 4. Potential for researcher bias due to repeated interactions, 5. Difficulty in maintaining consistent measurement over time.
